Consider also the 'golden rule' that many of us were taught by the larger society: Basically, treat others like one would like to be treated.


a. If an individual makes the larger society suffer, the larger society normally makes the individual suffer.


b. But now, if the larger society makes the individual suffer first, by prolonging the individuals life when the individual does not want to stay alive, especially for terminally ill people, then since the larger society did it to the individual first, that is obviously how the larger society wants to be treated.


c. Anybody who wants to end their life, especially terminally ill people but not only terminally ill people, but society does not make it legal for the individual to end their own life, would then have the inherent 'right' per the 'golden rule' to make society suffer, or at least prolong societies' suffering, since the larger society did it to the individual first and that must be how the larger society wants to be treated.


d. Hey, I didn't write the 'golden rule', but what is fair is fair. So, anybody who wants to end their own life and the larger society does not make it legal to do so, you would now have the right to make the larger society suffer, or at least prolong societies' suffering if the larger society is already suffering. The 'golden rule' is either the 'golden rule' or it's not.

I'm guessing this is Implicit Bias on the part of the writers and advisors, but out of all the philosophers mentioned only 2 were People of Color (and only male to boot). The majority of them were, in fact, straight. And the majority of the examples were Christian when talking about God. (I do get that Thought bubble and the images were carefully selected to have a variety of other examples, but authority figures should play into it too)

White feminism? I smell a version. Throw in token Chinese people, and done.

But I would have liked the basics of Eastern and Western Philosophy--which is something I enjoyed in my own High School classes (and Sunday School, though I'm Jewish--complicated story on how a Korean can be Jewish and going to Sunday school). And this section was completely skipped. Cultural relativism in philosophy is large and wide, but I believe it could at least be condensed. Things like "What is the nature of time?" is different in Western and Eastern Philosophy. But even those labels are reductive, because that's only covering usually (East and sometimes South) Asia and Greece/Roman bases. What happened to those other continents? Africa? or North and South America?

I think there was a huge missed opportunity by only covering White feminism's PoV on "What is Philosophy?" Sun Tzu, Confucius, and also the line between what is philosophy and what is religious thought? would be a good place to look more globally at "What is philosophy?" (There's got to be others as well.) By implicitly guessing that people are more interested in Christianity, is to also guess that the majority of your audience is in, fact, Christian. (Majority of the world's population, BTW, is Muslim, last I checked). If Crash Course reaches a worldwide audience, what makes it statistically likely that the majority of that audience will be Christian? What happened to other religions? I get other thoughts were covered, but they were rarely front lined.

BTW, for people that don't know. Implicit Bias is not always conscious, which is the argument against diversity blind. Being diversity aware makes you conscious of these discrepancies so you don't end up navel gazing at your own diversity. Even if you are diversity aware, implicit bias can make you still favor your own groups subconsciously and put other groups as a second thought, rather than a headline. And while it's not intentional, it can be insidious all the same. For example, the intention might be to educate in a wide field, but the impact might be, "Well, do black people, Latinx/Hispanic, Native peoples, Indigenous people also not have philosophers?" thus telling the People of Color, they rarely have important thinkers in past or present and white people that they are the most important in philosophy (even if this is subconscious). Of course people object to this reasoning, but usually those self-same people are the people who already have mirrors in the media they are viewing and are basking in privilege they aren't aware of.

That being said, I'd like to discuss and debate the realities of why people make the choices that they do. I feel like the dialogue has gone from what would be best for the mother's health and well-being toward, if you can afford it, controlling for the most desirable outcome if one were to go full term and create an autonomous human being (with its own body and its own choice).

What concerns me the most is that people aren't just aborting "disabled fetuses", they are aborting the idea of what those fetuses will become. They are having "selective" abortions motivated not by the quandary of "Do I want to be pregnant?", but instead motivated by "Do I want to bring a disadvantaged human into the world?"

For example, say you know that your child is likely to have down syndrome once it's born. The fact that you know this now changes the context of your abortion. It stops being a consideration of one's own body and it becomes about your judgement on whether people with down syndrome have the right to live. That's harsh, but a fetus with down syndrome poses no risk to itself or the mother and therefore if you have an abortion, you're having an abortion based on the reality of WHAT IT WILL BECOME and not what it is.

That means, essentially, by basing your decision on what your child might be, you're making a judgment on who has a right to live in the world and who doesn't. Using this type of thinking actually complicates everything. It's not simply about your body any more. Well, technically it is. Just because you have pre-cog on what your baby will become doesn't change the fact that it is in your body and you have a choice.

There is something strangely psychotic and consumerist about this concept. And prejudice, as if deformity or special needs = a less than fulfilling life. If you are able-bodied, how can we possibly make this judgement?

I would never take choice away. That is ridiculous. But I do question the ethics behind a choice to abort a fetus based on what that fetus might become in the future. It's a variation on eugenics and a dangerous way to think (I think) and we should be weary about what this type of thinking could lead to ethically. One horrible outcome: we might selectively breed out people with Downs from our gene pool.

What exactly matters into future eternity and to whom does it eternally matter to?
"God" alone? and/or "Me" too? and/or "Some other entity or entities"?
OR
"To no eternally consciously existent entity at all"?
(All of life itself would be ultimately meaningless. Even if "God" exists but is not truly eternally consciously existent.).

"The Suckiness of Life"
Life sucks and then we die and/or life does not suck and then we still die. Then we either have a life after this life, which would probably suck and/or not suck, or we wouldn't, and all suckiness for us would end for all of future eternity.

BUT, while we exist, if life sucks, try to make it better and then it might not suck so bad. BUT THEN, "better" for whom? If for an individual, which individual? If for a larger society, which larger society? There is a natural tension between the individual and the larger society of individuals. What is best for an individual, may or may not be what is best for the larger society. And conversely, what is best for the larger society, may or may not be what is best for the individual. But, we appear to be individuals in a society of individuals, we have to exist somehow, someway.

What do we, individually and as a society of individuals, choose? With all the consequences and ramifications, seen and unseen, of all our collective choices. Will we choose to have a pro-active space program that might save any conscious entities from this Earth before it is destroyed one way or another? Or, will we all choose to die here on Earth? Or, will we at least die trying to survive longer into the future, at least as a species if not even individually? Choices in life. To die, or to keep on living. What do we choose?

My stance on abortion is simple. At week 25, brain waves reach a regular rate signifying cognitive consciousness aka life. This is well after pregnancy is noticeable. Any abortions before week 25 are perfectly fine with me (unless doctors can prove regular EEG activity before then). After week 25 however, any abortions should only be 'mercy abortions' for example aborting a fetus with life crippling disabilities. This can be seen as a moral duty as proposed in the video. Any non 'mercy' related abortions at this point can't be far from murder. I understand that you may see contradictions being that even 'mercy' abortions are technically murder but I'd like to point out it can also be compared to assisted death, with the only difference being it is before the suffering begins. I came to this conclusion after 1/2 a year of research, debating among teachers and friends, rational logic and various opinions. I believe this to be the most reasonable conclusion.

Thing is, there are 2 kinds of suffering. Pain and regret. The source of pain is an event occurring which causes it. The source of regret is a longing for an event that did not occur. While it is possible to regret not avoiding an event that causes us pain, in this situation one would never prioritize the regret over the actual pain... because the pain generates the regret. However, when we regret the actions of others, we often lose sight of the fact that in order to avoid our own regret, others will suffer pain and then regret as well. The problem with the movement against things like medically motivated abortion and assisted dying is that those against it are only trying to avoid their own regret with no consideration for the suffering of those they would deny.

They believe that the fetus is the subject of argument, not the mother.

It's exactly the issue I saw in the Ken Ham vs Bill Nye debate. Instead of Nye trying to tackle Ham's ontological commitments (everything in the bible is true, smart people believe it, so that gives it merit, etc.) he totally ignored that and argued something that was completely foundationally disconnected from what Ham was arguing.
